Clinical: Diarrhoea. Perinaeum, pains in. Prostatic affections.
Characteristics: Mure figures and describes this plant. He made a proving of the leaves. On the second day of the proving the prover lost an inveterate diarrhoea with colic. The most notable symptoms were a pain in the perinaeum and testicles; and shuddering followed by heat without sweat.
Head: Vertigo.
Headache with sensitiveness of scalp.
Stool and Anus: Fearful pain and pulling from perinaeum to anus when sitting; not ceasing in any position, lasting six hours.
Lancinations in perinaeum, urethra, and testicles.
Urinary Organs: Urine: profuse; light foaming; red, odourless, with bloody clots; fetid; white sediment; albuminous.
Skin: Pricking over feet, ankles, and wrists.
Fever: Violent chills followed by heat without sweat.
